Name: Insectarium
Description: Dedicated to the wonders of bugs, the insectarium is home to more than 100 insect species, including butterflies, bees, beetles, and ants.
Fact: You can encounter butterflies, dragonflies and other creatures up close and personal inside our butterfly dome.

Name: Dinoroarus
Description: Experience the wonders of prehistoric life in Dinoroarus, a walk-through exhibit with life-size animatronic dinosaurs.
Fact: Dinoroarus takes the place of the Children's Zoo, which operated from 1969 until October 2020. The exhibit is temporary while the children's area is redeveloped.

Name: Bird House and Garden
Description: Explore aviaries, including a walk-through aviary, where you'll find a range of birds from cranes, parrots, toucans, and owls.
Fact: In the Bird House, you'll find a Toco toucan, which is the largest toucan species.

Name: Herpetarium
Description: Visit animals living in four different biomes inside the Herpetarium, including alligators, snakes, lizards, turtles and frogs.
Fact: The Herpetarium is home to a Malayan gharial, an endangered species. Look for the crocodilian with a very slender snout.

Name: Primate House
Description: Watch monkeys, lemurs, and apes interact, eat, and play inside the Primate House. The building is home to mongoose lemurs, Allen's swamp monkeys, and more species.
Fact: Females are dominant over males in most lemur species, including the ring-tailed lemur species you'll find in the Primate House.

Name: Flight Cage and Cypress Swamp
Description: Housed in the the historic Flight Cage, the Cypress Swamp is an immersive habitat you can enter. Inside you'll find a collection of aquatic birds, including snowy egrets, ducks and more.
Fact: The Flight Cage was built for the 1904 World's Fair, which was held in St. Louis.

Name: Sea Lion Sound
Description: Sea Lion Sound is home to both harbor seals and California sea lions. Both have whiskers and fall in the animal order of pinnipeds, meaning they are "fin-footed".
Fact: Sea lions can stay underwater for up to 20 minutes and can dive up to 1,000 feet deep.

Name: Stingrays at Caribbean Cove
Description: Get to know our graceful stingrays in a warm, 17,000 gallon touch pool. Guests can purchase food to feed the stingrays.
Fact: The touch pool also contains small sharks! No need to worry - the sharks are benign and aren't dangerous to guests, just a bit shy.

Name: Duck, Geese and Swan
Description: The lake inside the zoo is home to waterfowl species such as ducks and trumpeter swans.

Name: Capybara
Description: Capybara are native to South America and are known as the world's largest rodent. They're semi aquatic animals that generally live near lakes, rivers, and other bodies of water.
Fact: As semi aquatic mammals, capybara spend lots of time in the water and are strong swimmers. Capybara can hold their breath for up to 5 minutes!

Name: Anteater
Description: The anteaters in the zoo fall in the category of 'giant anteaters' and are the largest anteater species. In addition to their obvious food choice, anteaters also eat termites, beetle larvae and fruit.
Fact: The tongues of giant eaters can extend up to 2 feet. See if you can spot them eating!

Name: Cheetah
Description: Stop by and say hello to our cheetah family! In 2017 eight cheetah cubs were born as part of the zoo's efforts to support genetic diversity in the cheetah population.
Fact: Cheetahs are a threatened species, with fewer than 8,000 living in the wild.

Name: Hyena
Description: When visiting the spotted hyenas, listen for the laughing sounds they make to communicate. Hyenas live in desert and savanna areas in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Fact: Hyena's are skilled hunters as well as scavengers, eating everything from live prey to eggs and bone.

Name: Red Panda
Description: You're likely to spot our red panda napping on its tree stand platform, as red pandas are primarily active after dark.
Fact: Red pandas are an endangered species and are more closely related to raccoons than pandas.
